Award.AwardTitle: Problems in The Theory of Automorphic Forms and L-functions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Taking the lead from the recent progress in Langlands program, the investigator proposes a number of projects, both towards making new progress on functoriality as well as benefiting from what is available. The first includes a study of Langlands "Beyond Endoscopy" by means of both regular and relative trace formulas as well as the possibility of using other Poincar\'e series besides Eisenstein series on infinite dimensional groups with the hope of capturing the new adjoint actions that happen in the dual setting, since it now appears that Eisenstein series on these groups do not lead to any new L-functions. The second set of projects includes establishing the strong transfer from general spin groups as well as the transfer from quasisplit special orthogonal groups to GL(n); special value results for L-functions by means of Harder-Mahnkopf periods through functoriality as well as an attempt in using the Langlands-Shahidi method to obtain such results via certain ideas of Harder; a general theory of Bessel functions dictated by the investigator's work on local coefficients with an eye on proving stability for root numbers of symmetric and exterior square L-functions of GL(n), among others, as well as equality of root numbers obtained from different methods. Finally the investigator will study the singular residues of certain local intertwining operators hoping to interpret them as certain weighted orbital integrals, as well as other problems in representation theory of local groups and Lfunctions. Most of these projects are joint with other mathematicians.

Langlands Program is a vast collection of problems and conjectures which connects objects of arithmetic or geometric nature to those of analytic character. Such reciprocities are usually called "Functoriality". One example of this appeared in a fundamental way in the celebrated proof of Fermat's Last Theorem by Wiles. Throughout his career the investigator has developed a theory usually called the Langlands-Shahidi method, which through collaboration with a number of mathematicians, has recently led to a number of new and surprising cases of functoriality with consequences such as new bounds on eigenvalues of Laplacian on certain hyperbolic Riemann surfaces. The present proposal suggests a number of problems to try to extend functoriality to a larger class of cases as well as using them to establish new results in number theory and group representations. Among them is understanding the transcendental nature of values of L-functions, generalizations of Riemann zeta functions, at certain integers and half-integers, in line with integral values of the latter, as well as analyzing other analytic objects of arithmetic significance. The proposal involves training of graduate students and postdocs and collaboration with younger investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Number theory is a branch of mathematics where the problems are easy to explain but fairly hard to solve. To wit one should mention Fermat's last theorem in which one has to rule out, for each integer n > 2, the existance of any three non-zero integers x, y and z for which the sum of n-th powers of x and y equals that of z. The problem was solved three hundred years later by Andrew Wiles, a professor at Princeton, using the work many mathematicians developed over this period. Among the techniques used are those borrowed from the so called "Langlands Program", a vast collection of problems, techniques and results, named after Robert Langlands, now an emeritus professor at the Institue for Advanced Study at Princeton, NJ. The problems studied in this project are rooted in Langlands Program and have applications both within the program as well as number theory and representation theory, a subject whose conception lies within quantum physics.

Among the conjectures proposed in the Langlands Program are those of reciprocity laws between two sets of seemingly different objects. Reciprocity laws are fairly deep. For example, they could relate representations of groups of arithmetic nature, generlizations of Galois groups and so on, to those of analytic nature, adelic or local groups in this context. While these are very hard to establish one may try to connect representations for groups of same nature. This is usually called "the functoriality principle"  in the context of the program. Among the results obtained in this project is a case of functoriality between representations of two families of adelic groups, general linear groups and the so called general spin groups. While the first class can be presented by matrices of size n, the second basically  will be given by matrices of size 2 to the power n. But remarkably enough representations of the second set are part of those of the first kind.

Techniques involved in establishing this result are those of L-functions. These are functions of one complex variable which are generalizations of the famous Riemann zeta function and are given by infinite products of local factors which make sense originally in a subset of comlex plane.  A major part of this project deals with establishing furthur properties of these functions and developing techniques that allow us to relate these objects to their arithmetic counterparts through the reciprocity laws explained earlier.  Considerable progress is made in the study of these objects and understanding their values at certain special integers. These are related to conjectures of Deligne, one of the leading number theorists in the world.

The project also involves training of  graduate students and postdocs through their direct supervision as well as graduate courses taught at Purdue and other NSF funded summer schools through NSF focused research group grants(FRG) elsewhere.

The principal investigators has served in editorial boards of a number of prominent mathematical journals over this period. He has also been involved in advising and training of minorities at different levels.
